content.content: #### Ask Questions! __No question is too trivial to ask. Trust your instincts.__ __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about yourself or your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") 1\. Write down all your questions to ask your doctor or nurse or ask someone to do it for you.[^7] 2\. Bring a family member or advocate to help listen and speak up for you. Embedded content: https://youtu.be/MEFJfpKslQg 3\. Bring the patient's medication and allergy list to show the doctor and nurse.[^10] [Personal Medicine List from ISMP](https://www.pihhealth.org/app/files/public/6622387d-5fa4-4a61-a14d-d72f25e1f224/Personal-Medicine-List.pdf "Personal Medicine List from ISMP") 4\. Don't distract the nurse while they are giving medications.__ Ask questions before!__[^7] [5 Questions to Ask About Your Medications from ISMP Canada](https://www.ismp-canada.org/download/MedRec/MedSafety_5_questions_to_ask_poster.pdf) [Taking Medications- What to Ask Your Doctor from MedlinePlus](https://medlineplus.gov/ency/patientinstructions/000535.htm "Taking Medications-What to Ask Your Doctor from MedlinePlus") 5\. __Ask questions respectfully about everything:__ [^10] - Ask for a drug information sheet with every new medication. - Why do I need this medication? - What is the medication for? - What will it do? - When do I take the first dose? - How often should this medication be taken? - How much should be taken? - What does "as needed" mean? - How do you get refills? - When will I stop taking this medication? - What are the side effects &/or possible drug interactions? - Where do I get the medication? - Will my insurance pay for this medication? - Are there any foods or drinks that should be avoided? - Can I drive after taking this medication? - __Tell your doctor if you stop taking this or any medication.__ - Can you explain that to me again? [Opioids After Surgery from ISMP Canada ](https://www.ismp-canada.org/download/OpioidStewardship/OpioidsAfterSurgery-EN.pdf) Embedded content: https://youtu.be/od6ksU6IIAE 6\. Write in your phone, mobile device, computer or notebook with the answers given:[^7] - What is the test, procedure, medication and/or surgery for? - How many times have you done this test or procedure? - When will the results be back? - Why do I need this treatment? - Are there any alternatives? - What are the complications? [10 Questions You Should Know from the Agency for Healthcare and Research Quality ](https://www.ahrq.gov/patients-consumers/patient-involvement/ask-your-doctor/10questions.html) 7\. Repeat back or "teach back" medication, treatment &/or self-care instructions to your doctor &/or nurse.[^12] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/3qY8Of06qFU 8\. If a doctor tells you your medication or treatment plan has changed, ask your nurse if the orders have been changed.[^7] [Your Medicine: Be Smart. Be Safe from AHRQ ](https://www.ahrq.gov/patients-consumers/patient-involvement/ask-your-doctor/tips-and-tools/yourmedques.html) 9\. Doctors must write the hospital orders for drugs, tests, procedures and the treatment plan.[^7] [Tests and Procedures from the Mayo Clinic](http://www.mayoclinic.org/tests-procedures/index?letter=C) 10\. Ask your doctor: “Could this be anything else?”[^14] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/ug1lcApreiQ [Checklist for Getting the Right Diagnosis from the National Patient Safety Foundation ](https://cdn.ymaws.com/www.npsf.org/resource/collection/930A0426-5BAC-4827-AF94-1CE1624CBE67/Checklist-for-Getting-the-Right-Diagnosis.pdf) [6 Tips for Talking With Your Doctor from CAPS ](https://www.healthgrades.com/right-care/patient-advocate/6-tips-for-talking-to-your-doctor) 11\. At the change of shift, ask the patient's nurses to compare notes at the patient's bedside.[^10] ![Nurse Bedside](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6fG4qjqwvKAokC82CQssc4/e66a424bb2de3ed15ded931a1393fb0e/Nurse_Bedside.jpg) 12\. Call the nurse if the patient doesn't seem right or if the alarm goes off. [^7][^10] 13\. Call the nurse if the patient has: [^7][^10] - Extreme pain - Fever or chills - Redness, swelling, &/or pus - Confusion - Difficulty breathing - Very slow breathing - Dizziness - Unusual sweating - Rash or hives - Drop in blood pressure - High or low temperature - Changes in heart rate - Changes in breathing - Decrease in urine - Patient doesn’t look right __Listen to your gut or intuition.__ If no one is listening to you, speak with the Nurse Manager. [^7][^10] __Adult and children normal vital signs are below:__ [^16][^17] - Normal body temperature is 97.8 degrees Fahrenheit to 99 degrees Fahrenheit. - Normal adult heart rate is 60 to 100 beats per minute. - Normal adult breathing rate is 12 to 16 breathes per minute. - Normal adult blood pressure is less than 120/80 mm Hg. __Pediatric Respiratory Rates:__ | Age | Breaths per minute | |-------------------------|--------------------| | Infant (birth to 1 yr.) | 30 to 60 | | Toddler (1-3 yrs.) | 24 to 40 | | Preschooler (3-6 yrs.) | 22 to 34 | | School age (6-12 yrs.) | 18 to 30 | | Adolescent (12-18 yrs.) | 12 to 16 | __Pediatric Heart Rates per Minute__ | Age | Awake | Sleeping | |---------------------|------------|-----------| | Newborn to 3 months | 85 to 205 | 80 to 160 | | 3 months to 2 yrs. | 100 to 190 | 75 to 160 | | 2 yrs. to 10 yrs. | 60 to 140 | 60 to 90 | | 10 yrs. to 18 yrs. | 60 to 100 | 50 to 90 | __Low-Normal Pediatric Systolic Blood Pressure__ | Age | Low-Normal | |------------------------------|-----------------| | Infant (Birth-1 yr.) | Greater than 60 | | Toddler (1 yr.-3 yrs.) | Greater than 70 | | Preschooler (3 yrs.-6 yrs.) | Greater than 75 | | School Age (6 yrs.-12 yrs.) | Greater than 80 | | Adolescent (12 yrs.-18 yrs.) | Greater than 90 | ### Medical Device Questions:[^18] - How many procedures have you done with this device? - Have any patients had problems? - Have you ever removed this device? - Has this device ever been recalled? - What are the risks and alternative treatments? - Does this device have a black box warning or contraindications? - What is the device made of, and what can be done if an adverse reaction to the materials occurs? - Have you had any financial relationship with the manufacturer of this device? 1. Research any device that will be used on or in you. [^18] 2. Get a 2nd opinion for any risky or expensive procedure.[^18] 3. Find out if the device has had any recalls.[^18] 4. Look at [ProPublica’s Dollars for Devices](https://projects.propublica.org/docdollars/) or [Open Payments Data from CMS](https://openpaymentsdata.cms.gov) to find out if your MD has received money from the device company.[^18] 5. Research your MD’s experience with medical devices at [ProPublica’s Surgeon Scorecard](https://projects.propublica.org/surgeons/).[^18] ### Healthcare Providers - Ask all medical staff for their business card.[^7] - Write down or have someone write down the medical staff’s names if no card is given.[^7] - Be aware that the medical team may not speak with each other, as they should.[^7] [Who's Who in the Hospital by the Empowered Patient Coalition](http://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Resources_Forms_Whos_Who_in_the_Hospital.pdf) [Top Ten Tips for Talking with your Doctor from LifeSpan](https://lifespanohio.org/talk-doctor/ "Top Ten Tips for Talking with your Doctor from LifeSpan") [^7]: Hallisey J. The Empowered Patient® hospital guide for patients and families. Empowered Patient website. http://engagedpatients.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/empowered_patient_hospital_guide.pdf. Published 2009. Updated 2012. Accessed May 10, 2015. [^10]: Curtiss K. Campaign. ZERO-Patient Safety Checklist. http://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Resources_Checklist_Patient_Safety_Checklist_Collection.pdf. Accessed November 5, 2015. [^12]: Kornburger C, Gibson C, Sadowski S, Maletta K, Klingbeil C. Using "teach-back" to promote a safe transition from hospital to home: an evidence based approach to improving the discharge process. J Pediatr Nurs. 2013;28(3):282-91. doi: 10.1016/j.pedn.2012.10.007. Accessed July 16, 2018. [^14]: Gloopman J. How Doctors Think. Chapter 7, page 167, Boston, MA: Houghton Miflin; 2007. [^16]: University of Rochester Medical Center. Vital signs (body temperature, pulse rate, respiration rate, blood pressure). URMC Health Encyclopedia website. https://www.urmc.rochester.edu/encyclopedia/content.aspx?ContentTypeID=85&ContentID=P00866. Published 2017. Accessed April 27, 2017. [^17]: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services. Pediatric basic and advanced life support. Chemical Hazards Emergency Medical Management website. https://chemm.nlm.nih.gov/pals.htm. Updated June 25, 2011. Accessed April 27, 2017. [^18]: Medical Device Problems. Resources. Medical Device Problems website. http://www.medicaldeviceproblems.com/resources#questions. Published 2018. Accessed August 15, 2018.
